title.narrative: Development Of The Climate Action Plans According To The Gcom Common Reporting Framework

description.narrative:
The Socialist Republic of Vietnam, considered among the most vulnerable countries in the world to the impacts of climate change. Vietnam also is one of the parties to the UNFCCC who immediately ratified the Paris Agreement in 2016 and submitted its NDC to the Convention. In its (intended) NDC crafted in 2015 and which is currently being reviewed, the government has targeted for an economy-wide GHG emissions reduction of 8% by 2030 as compared to business as usual when using domestic funds, and up to 25% if with international support. In 2016, the government issued the Plan for Implementation of the Paris Agreement (PIPA) that specifies 68 specific tasks expected to ensure achievement of the country’s NDC, which stands as its contribution to the global climate agreement whilst fully recognizing the national priorities and circumstances. Considering the importance of multi-level climate governance, the PIPA strategically outlined the tasks and responsibilities for sectors as well as the localities that include provinces and cities.
Vietnam cities and urban centers are crucial in achieving the national and global targets for climate change. The efforts at the sub-national level would be pivotal to ensure resilient and low-emission development in Vietnam noting that urban population is expected to grow from the current 35% to 50% in 2045 and foreseeing a sustained economic growth which has averaged to about 7% annually over the last two decades. Climate actions in Vietnam cities are crucial since (1) an approximate 75% of the urban population in Vietnam are living in low-elevation coastal zones, and (2) the changing lifestyle and carbon-intensive energy mix may increase the GHG emission per capita of 3.5 tones CO2e to ten-fold consistent to the projected 10 times GDP growth rate increase from 2010-2050.
UN-Habitat has been partnering with national government agencies such as Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment and cities across the country to promote climate resilience interventions both at policy level and programmes that are with more tangible results at the ground.
In short term, UN Habitat actions under this will contribute to Vietnam cities and the government on developing their Climate Action Plans (CAPs) consistent with the national policies and issuances in line with globally accepted reporting standards and framework that is promoted by GCOM.
